ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: NA

This was by far my favorite course this semester, and one of the most useful courses I've taken at F&ES. Ann is a true teacher as well as a scientist, which is a quality that I believe academic institutions should value over everything else. I would suggest Stand Dynamics to anyone with an interest in forest development and management.

This course required a lot more reading than I was expecting, and more theory. It also required some self direction, as there were never really any "guidelines" per se for the assignments. The field trip was AMAZING and Professor Camp is wonderful.

-Course was perfect other than the exams, which didnt motivate much in terms of work (I did all of the reading for the course, not because of the grade-motivation, it being grad school, but because I felt I needed to learn the material). The exams did motivate last-minute terminology memorization, which makes me think that itd be useful to hand out a glossary of terms that summarized each for students. -Anns experience as a practitioner was really valuable for the course, and its a real shame that shes retiring. F&ES should have made a stronger effort to keep her; this is a classic example of how the narrow-minded focus on research-based academic experience is a detriment to the school. Ann was by far my best teacher this fall, perhaps because she had made a conscious decision earlier in her time at F&ES to focus on her pedagogy instead of on research. A narrow-minded emphasis on research and publication cuts out practitioners for certain disciplines (e.g., urban forestry; how many urban forestry researchers looking to join academic faculty are there versus the number of folks who have actually practiced urban forestry?)weakening the schools offerings. This research/publication emphasis also goes against the goal of the school, which is, in my understanding, to train professional practitioners using the best available science. A course with a practitioner (and one who also, but not exclusively, did innovative research!) like Ann is far more valuable than one with a researcher who has been holed up in their conceptual echo chamber for the past few decades. And of course, there is some question in my mind whether an anti-practitioner bias inadvertently (assuming the best of intentions) discriminates against women and ethnic minorities, by limiting the pool of eligibility to the traditional bastion of white male patriarchy: the academy. Yales current solution seems to be to offer less-than-tenure-track-positions (e.g., lecturer) to the female practitioners, reserving the tenure track for the male researchers who have been around the academy for longer. Is that really a viable solution?
The field trip to Great Mountain was a lot of fun, but we did not go over much that I hadn't already learned before.
I love the class and I'm sorry to see Ann go. I won't every look at forests the same way.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The instructor's knowledge and familiarity with the topic, as well as extensive field experience.
Very clear lectures and well structured in-class discussions.

This seems like half-joke response but it is not: I learned what I expected to, in the way I hoped to learn it, by taking this course. Ann lectures with confidence and a passion that is tangible, and she comes with a high level of experience as a scientist/researcher in the field. Most importantly, she expects students to put in the time and effort to master material. This is not a class where you can tune out until the end of the semester and then throw together a quick final project to squeak by. Ann holds students accountable, but she also holds herself to a high standard of teaching. We could use many more of her here.
The field trip to Great Mountain Forest was very, very fun. It's nice to get to know classmates a little bit better and Professor Camp really fostered a nice ambiance.

This class is a great introduction to the processes of forests, and the main drivers behind their dynamics. Though this class had a heavier reading load than others, it introduced me to a wide range of research and literature that I can build on for the rest of my time at FES. The student presentations the last few weeks of class were definitely the highlight.
The student presentations at the end of the semester.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: No improvement needed
NA
I have no critiques.
There could have been more information given about expectations of the assignments.
It might have been useful to spend less time on lectures, and more time discussing the readings and how they apply to concepts discussed in class.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: NA

Yes! I initially really dreaded the days where we discussed our readings, but over time I found these classes to be very helpful for processing information. This class also built my confidence in voicing my thoughts in whole-group discussions, which is something I have struggled with in courses where my background knowledge is not strong.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am a Master of Forest Science student with research focusing on forest regeneration dynamics, so this course was crucial to my program of study and the work that I plan on doing.
Good foundational knowledge for forested landscapes.

Though I certainly wouldn't push this actively, I think any student graduating from the Yale School of Forestry should have at least a little bit of forestry knowledge. Ann provides an excellent learning platform for people with all levels of previous experience in this course. I came into Stand Dynamics as an MESc student who has not taken a forestry course since undergrad--which was a few years ago--and I found this course to be very helpful. I have friends with more and less experience who have voiced similar opinions. This course has shifted my research interests so that forestry dynamics are more at the forefront. It has been one of the most impactful courses I've taken at F&ES.
This course was very relevant to the MF, MFS, and MESc degrees. The needs of these students should be upheld after Ann leaves.
This course is very relevant to my degree track, and I expect the concepts to provide a solid framework for my academic studies moving forward.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: See question 17
See above.

I initially signed up for this course to help me understand stand dynamics as a variable in my masters research. I have ultimately gained more than I expected, and my main research interests have shifted with this new knowledge.
For fun!
I took this course because how forests develop is an integral part of my education in forest science and management.
I had been told that it is an essential course for anyone pursuing a degree in forestry, and that Ann would be a great professor, so I should catch her before she leaves!

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
Yes, and then some.
Yes
Absolutely

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: NA

I participated informally in a study group, and I found this to be very useful. My peers often helped me understand challenging concepts, and talking through problems with them strengthened my confidence in the material.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Professor Camp is retiring, so I can't speak to who might be teaching it yet, but I would recommend it to every forestry student, as well as anyone who has ever wanted to learn more about what goes on in the forest.
Have fun!
You should! This course will challenge you in fair ways, and it will greatly impact the way you see forest development and the management implications associated with that development.

I believe the professor who teaches this course will change next year. Professor Camp was pretty much the best thing about the course, so I don't know how to answer this question. Pay attention to how important the readings are and decide whether you will be able to do all of them. They are important--and a lot more work than you might expect!

Because this course will not be taught by the same instructor it is hard to know what to expect, but having at least a cursory understanding of the readings will make a huge difference in the course. And start working on your presentation early!
Do the readings!!!
